metadata.title: Phase 1: Cases + Rules Demo
metadata.description: Walkthrough of Case Types, Rules, Cases, and Review Queue features

steps.narration: Welcome to the BlueMarble Intelligence Platform. Let's start by signing in.
We'll sign in with the admin account.
Let's start with Case Types. This is where we define the schema for different kinds of cases, like billing disputes or service complaints.
Here we can see the Billing Dispute case type. It defines the schema for billing dispute cases.

Let's view the details. Each case type defines its fields, SLA configuration, and a case number prefix. This billing dispute type has five fields including customer ID, dispute amount, reason, and transaction date.
The SLA configuration sets response time to thirty minutes, resolution time to twelve hours, and auto-escalation after four hours.
Now let's look at the Rules page. Rules define the business logic for routing and resolving cases automatically.
Here's our Auto-Resolve Small Overcharges rule.
Let's see the conditions in detail.

This rule has three conditions. Small overcharges under fifty dollars are auto-resolved. High-value disputes over five hundred dollars are escalated to a manager. And unauthorized charges go to the fraud team. Anything else falls through to the default action, which assigns it to the billing team queue.
Now let's see the Cases page. These are actual case instances that have been created and processed.

We have three cases. B D twenty-twenty-six zero zero zero one was a thirty dollar overcharge that was auto-resolved. Zero zero zero two is a seven hundred fifty dollar duplicate charge that was escalated. And zero zero zero three was an unauthorized charge that was resolved by a human agent after investigation.
Let's look at the detail view for the unauthorized charge case.

The case detail shows the full audit trail. Every action is tracked â€” creation, escalation, assignment, investigator notes, and final resolution. This complete history is critical for compliance and review.
Finally, let's visit the Review Queue. This is where escalated cases land for human review.

The review queue shows cases sorted by priority with SLA countdown timers. Reviewers can claim cases, add investigation notes, and resolve them. This gives the operations team a clear view of what needs attention.

That concludes Phase 1 of the User-Query Journey. We've delivered case types with configurable schemas and SLA tracking, a rule engine with first-match-wins evaluation, full case lifecycle management with audit trails, and a review queue for escalated cases. Twenty-three new MCP methods power the entire feature. Thank you for watching.
